which almost render fancy a n d philosophy analogous.
T h e r e if. n fervour—a fratikne»s in his style which we d o
not reoogriijM' in a n \ other modern author. T h e r e IN a

I t s announcement for
every evening was received with loud a n d unanimous

To the Public.
OPINIONS OF THE P B l H i i
" Filial affection, or rather what may b e ©nlled t h e
domestic feeling;, is t h e leading feature of Knowles'
new ptay, 7A* Maid of Mariendorpt,
a n d certain conceptions a n d situations a r e p e r h a p s m o r . powerful,
original, a n d striking;, than any t h i n g h e h a * produced.
Lund and unanimous a p p l a u s e followed t h e descent of
t h e ttirtain, a n d Knowles announced h i s drama for
repetition amid repeated aceln muttons. '•—The Time*.
" Knowles' poetry is that of n a t u r e , while it is characterized, at t h e same t i m e , by t h o s e abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
T h e r e is a fervour—a frankness in his style which vie do
not recognize in any other modern author. T h e r e i« a
genuine s t a m p of phtlanthrophy impressed on every p a g e ,
enlculnted a t o n e t o refine t h e feelings, and t o ennoble
t b . m a n . " — T h e Weekly
Dispatch.
" Mr K n o w l e s h a s availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Village of Marie tutor pi, find
treating it with ' a lihernl h a r d , h a s made it eiFeetively
subservient to his purpose. T h e plot is strongly pathetic.
T h e r e WHS m u c h applause b e s t o w e d on the play th.-.mgho u t its o r d e a l , a n d a t the e n d Knowles w a s culled forth
with g e n e r a l acclaim."—Morning
Herald.
" It is a composition of simple yet s t r o n g i n t e r e s t ;
and with t h e smile* that it provokes it b l e n d s a pathos
that come* direct from t h e most ' suorcd fount of sympathetic tears." T h e natural interests of its titu-itions.
particular scenes of h u m o u r a n d p a t h o s , t h e p o e t i c !
eharaeter of t h e diction insure for it a popularity which
t h e a u t h o r ' s exertions merit
I t s announcement foi
every eveningr was received with loud a n d Utteruatoos
a p p l a u s e "—Mornin<i Chronicle
" As n rhrwBttin work wo like !'{<• Maui of Marten—
dorpt more t h a n 'Ihe Lore Chatt.
lt« plot is well
imagined, it« interest vvell stu-ltuned, a n d it* |
many p a s s a g e * full of a b o u n d i n g b e a u t y , charity, a n d
human love. In its production Sheridan Knowie* muy
h e said t o h a v e added another laurel to h i s head and to
his h e a r t ; and when his work closed with th< usual i n d i cations of triumphant success, ho w a s "nlled for to.
i t m u o w a its repetition amid bursts of enthusiasm. P r a i a .
IN d u e for producing,— with such f o o d a p p o i n t s
and such g o o d acting,'—so beautiful oi>d attractive a.
dramatic production."—Morning Past.
" A i the story unfolded, w e felt assured of its n i l t\ |
and when t h e curtain dropped upon the third and iourtla
acts, t h e audience m n t l h a p p y to relieve tbemaeivca
of their excited feelings m overwln Iming bursts csf

WaidofMariendorpt
EVERY

EVENING,

To the

Public.

OFIIIOIi OE THD P R i i i i
*' Filial affection, or rather wlu»t may b e called t i t .
domestic feeling, is l b * lending feature of KiKiwIee'
new p-ty, The Ala id ©/ Mariendorpt,
and certain conceptions and situations are perhaps more powerful,
original, and striking', than urn thing tie has produced,
l / i u d and unanimous applause followed the descent of
t h . curtain, and Knowles announced his drama for
repetition amid reptmied acclamations, ' — T h e 'Times.
" Knowlcs' poetry is that of nature, while it ia charseterixed, at t h - s a m e time, by t h o s e abstract qualities
which almost render fancy and philosophy analogous.
T h e r e is a fervour—« frankness in his style which we do
not recognise in any other modern author. T h e r e is a
genuine stamp of philaiithrophy impressed on every p a g e ,
calculated a t onoe t o refine the foelings, and to ennoble
the r o a n . " — l \ e W e e k l y
Dispatch.
" Mr. K n o w l e s h a s availed himself of an incident in
Miss Porter's novel of The Village of kfanendbrpt,
R«d
treating it with • a lihernl h a n d , h a s made it effectively
subservient to his purpose. T h e plot is strongly pathetie.
T h e r e was much applause bestowed on the piny t h r o u g h out its ordeal, and nt the end K n o w l e s Was culled forth
with general declaim."—Morning
Herald.
" I t is a composition of simple yet s t r o n g i n t e r e s t ;
and with the smiles that it provokes it blends a pathos
that comes direct from the roo«.t ' ..acred fount of sympathetic tears.* T h e natural interests of its situations,
particular scenes of humour and pntho«, the poetical
<'harncter of the diction insure for it a popularity which
the author's exertions merit.
I t s announcement for
.•very evening was received with loud and unanimous
nprdnuse * — Morning
Ckronirle.
" As a dramatic work w e like The Maid of Mariend»i*t>» more than Ike IjOre Uhetse. U s plot is woll
imagined, its interest well sustained, and its poetry in
roanv passages full of a b o u n d i n g beauty, charity, and
human love. In its production Sheridan K n o w l e s may
be said to have added another Inurel to his h e a d and tc
his h e a r t ; and when his work closed with the usual indications of triumphant success, h e was called for t o
announce, its repetition amid bursts of enthusiasm. P r a i a ,
is due for producing,— with such good appointments,
nnd such g o o d acting,—so beautiful and attractive a
dramatic p r o d u c t i o n . " — M o m m y Poxt
" As the story unfolded, we felt assured of its safety ;
nnd when the curtain dropped upon the third and fourth
a c t s , the a u d i e n c e seemed h a p p y to relieve themselves
of their excited feelings in o v e r w h e l m i n g bursts of
T h e piece was completely successful."—The
a p p l a uIS*.
se
Conner.
" W h e n Kno'vles came forward tn announce the repetition of the piece, the audience greeted him with
acclamations, which must have been « . grateful to him
as they are deserved by him."—The Globe.
" T h e talented author of FtrtflMM, Tk»
llunekbark,
The L*>ve Oha$t, &c, has a d d e d fresh laurels t o his fame
in the production of another drama of that elastic beauty,
philosophic sublimity, and sterling character which had
already won for him the admiration and g r a t i t u d e of n
discerning and delighted public
It afforded us, therefore, no small a m o u n t of m e a s u r e to witness the zealous
and fervent enthusiasm which crowned with success his
latest effort." -Shipping
Gazette.
" T h e p l a y is crowded with fine things, worthy of th*
jjenius of S'hendau Knowles."—Atlas.

" T h o discrimiuntiog ptildie is again indebted to Mr.
.Sheridan Knowles for one of those sparkling emanations
of poetic g e n i u s which are imperishably interwoven with
his name upon the records of our dramatic literature.
T h e humanities never have been m o r e delightfully pourt r a j e d than in this play. I t is full of passages of impassioned eloquence ; and, as an effective drama appealing'
to our most holy sympathies, we consider it superior t o
any of his former productions " — W e e k l y
Ckrontcle,
" Since the production of The Maid of
Mariendorpt,
a few slight, but judicious alterations, b a r . had the effect
of m a k i n g the action of the drama g o more harmoniously,
rendering it a l t o g e t h e r more c o m p a c t and united. T h .
loves of Hans a n d E s t h e r is the most l a u g h a b l e episode
i m a g i n a b l e , and were there n o t h i n g else in t h . play,
would make it run a s e a s o n . ' — M o r n i n g
Advertiser.
" Tne Maid of Mariendorpt is worthy of Mr K n o w l e . '
reputation as a dramatic writer. It sparkles with poetic,
beauties throughout, while some of the scenes a r .
managed with the g r e a t e s t dramatic skill, and is sure t o
attain to great popularity."— Tke Observer.
" T h e merit of The Maid of Mariendorpt
is so g r e a t ,
that no living author save Knowles cot>!d have written it ;
and it would b e difficult t o point out anything on the
s t a g e finer than the whole of the fourth act. 1 he getting
u p of the play reflects the highest credit on the m a n a g e m e n t ; the dresses were admiiahle, and the whole of the
details carefully looked to. W o doubt not hut every o n .
who values a national poet and n national drama, will go
and see The Maid of Mariendorpt,
nnd give due h o n o u r s
to the author."—The Age.
" T h e object of tho d r a m a t i c has been to give a faithful
portrait of exalted filial affection.— the affection o f a
d a u g h t e r to a beloved and indulgent parent. T h . main
end of the drama is to carry out and pourtray this b e a u tiful, this s u h l i m . feeling—all our sensibilities urn
interested—none of our senses excited- -it is a play of the
heart and the mind
Another aim lias been t o break
down the barriers of prejudice between the Jew and the
Christian; and t h e whole of these efforts are successful
t h r o u g h a vein of poetry which seems gushing from t h .
fountain of the heart."— The Era.
" W e need scarcely add, t h . play was perfectly s u c cessful. I t had been carefully put upon the s t a g e , and
Mr. Koowles, amid enthusiastic cheering, announced i t
for repetition every evening."— The
Examiner
" T h e plot of this play is simple, but t h r o u g h o u t t h e
piece interest is kept alive, until in t h e third act that
interest deepens, ana is carried in the fourth to the highest
dramatic climax. It w as received t h r o u g h o u t most favourably by » crowded house, and at its close, the curtain fell
amid thunders of a p p l a u s e . " — S u n d a y Times.
" W e have nightly seen Mr. Knowles" new play of The
Maid of Mariendorpt
with increased pleasure, and a t
each repetition we have discovered fresh beauties, in
either the sentiments expressed, or in t h e construction of
the dialogue."—T»> Crown.
'* O n Tuesday, a new play, from the pen of Mr. Sheridan
K n o w l e s , and called The Maid of Marundorpt,
was
produced hern with perfect s u c c e s s ; — t h e a u t h o r has
drawn i t so intense, and w r o u g h t it out with so many
vivid beauties of poetry and striking s t a g e tableaux, t h a t
we a r e bound to oonfess to its having completely t u r n e d
t h e audience a l o n g to a finale attended by most unanimous
a p p l a u s e , and, we have no doubt, will fill the house for

many a night to uome-"-— Literary Gaxntte.

Mr. WEBSTER hege leave most respectfully to Inform the Public, that
an arrangement was entered Into with the accredited agent of l i r .
P O W E R to perform here on Dec. the 5th. ? Mr. P* purposing to leave
Hew Yorktoythe Great Western •team ship on the 22nd of Nov.. which
had she performed the voyage in twelve days and a half as she had done*
i^vious!*' with an ailverse wind, would have enabled him to have
ilfilled his contracts hut from some unforeseen circumstance, his departure from that city was delayed until the 2 l l h * wheuee he would
•all for Liverpool in one of Hie regular packets, called TPliC ROSCI1JS.
H e is consequently hourly expected, and every publicity will toe given
of his arrival.
To atone for the disappointment, Mr. W . has succeeded in engaging

S

F O R S I X N I G H T S ONLY,
The celebrated

Mr.

American Comedian,

H I L L ,

So Justly popular for his delineation of Yankee peculiarities, and he
will aonear in two of his favorite characters every evening.

he has received a letter from Mr. POWER* informing: him, that M r . P .

03jr Then- is hardly a lonely volley or wild mountain r-nare In all Irelnnd, that Is not diaracterlznl hi m m m tlt-noUn- the rBBJllanilB, or haunt of the " O n * .
P . ( i p | . t , a . "AlBiBa," and the belief that these elfin Inhnbitanta of earth and air occasionally ennd vend to Interfere with mortals, either In mirth or In malaee,
•till linger, among,! tbepeBiantry, one of the most poetical of our nntlonal auperatitiona, and highly congenial to the temperament of an ImaglnatWe people.
Tbla Drama, however, presents the " Good People" In dr< am only, the action of the piece, from the time the ftlriSB appear, unlil the sleeping O'Flannigan
awakes once more to a working day world, existing only in the creations of a wild fellow's brain fired hy whiskey, and disordered hy hard blows. Hla
Imaginary perils and suffering* being at MM the conseqaenee of his intemperance, and the moral punishment of the relapsed whiskey lover.

ftj" Ther* U hardly a lonely valley or wild mountain ranfte in all Inland, that isnut characterized In naiiifi denoting the residence, or haunt of the " ( l o o .
P - o r M i , o a F A I « I « S , " and HIP belief that these f ' / n inhabitant, of earth and air occasionally condescend to interfere with mortal,. either iti mirth orinraalare,
still lingers amongst the peasantry, one of the most poetical of our national auperatition*, and highly congenial to the temperament of an im»frlnativ* people.
Thl» Drama, however, present* the '* Good People'- In dream only, the action of the piece, from the time the fairies appear, until the sleeping O'Flanni'an
awakes once more to a working day world, eiistlng only in the creations of a wild fellow's brain find by whiskey, nnd disordered by bard blows. His
imaginary perils and Buttering* being at once the eonseqaence of his intemperance, and the moral punishment of the relapsed whiskey lover.

THE ONLY SUCCESSFUL CHRISTMAS PIECE.

O'FLANNIGAN
AND THE FAIRIES;
OR,

A Blidsummer Night's Dream,-not Shakspeare s.
M * : : ~J*f*

OPINIONS OF T i l l ! PRESS.
u

One of the best Christmas Pieces t h a t l u r e
been produced is t h e a m u . i n g e x t r a v a g a n t
brought out a t t h e H a y m a r k e t , a n d called
O ' F L A N N I O A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , a dramatizing
of t h e Irish fairy legend, called, « Hie over t o
Sttglaad.' T h e r e are several amusing scenes in
t h e course of t h e pieee, one of t h e best being
the fair scene, with a skirmish among t h e hoys,
ending with not a few broken heads. I t were,
perhaps, needless to say that, as to Power was
entrusted the task of delineating the peculiarities
of a light-hearted
and light-headed broth of a
boy, he acquitted h i m s e l f o f h i s task, and t h e
piece was given out for repetition without a d i s sentient voiee'."—Cowr* Journal.

" T h e principal piece was O ' F L A N N I O A N
A N D T H K F A I R I E S , the plot of which turns on
the mystification wliich besots a good humoured
native of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza afforded an opportunity for the introduction
of P O W E R , whoso rich humour, combined with
his genuine Irish manner, kept the house in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to t h e end of
the performance.
' O ' F I a n . i g a n ' s appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The Timet.

A N D T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A

was produced for the first time, Mr. P O W E R infused into it all his wonted point and spirit, and

lias been got u p in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, and w a s most

THE ONLY SUCCESSFUL CHRISTMAS PIECE.

O'FLANNIGAN
AND THE FAIRIES!
OK,

¥

A Midsummer N i g h t s Dream, not Shakspeare's.
OPINIONS o r

VIIE

" One of the b . s t Christmas Pieces that have
been produced is t h e a m u s i n g extravaganza
brought out at t h e H a y m a r k e t , a n d (tailed
O ' F L A N N I O A N A N D T H N F A I R I E S , a dramatizing
of t h e Irish fairy legend, called, ' Hie over to
England.' T h e r e are several amusing scenes in
the course of t h e pieee, one of the best being
the fair scene, with a skirmish among t h e boys,
ending with not a few broken heads. I t were,
perhaps, needless to say that, as to Power was
entrusted the task of delineating the peculiarities
of a light-lienrted
and light-headed broth of a
boy, he acquitted himself of his task, and t h e
piece was given out for repetition without a dissentient voiee."—Court Journal.

" T h e principal p i . e e was O ' F L A N N I O A N
AND T H E F A I R I K K , th* plot of which turns on
the mystification which besets a good humoured
native of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza afforded an opportunity for the introduction
of P O W E R , whose rich humour, combined with
his genuine Irish manner, kept the house* in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
' O ' F l a n . i g a n ' s appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The. Times.

" O ' F L A N N I G A N AND T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A
M I D S U M M E R N I G H T ' S Df.*AM,(«o<Shakspeare's]

was produced for the first time. Mr. P o w E R infused into it all his wonted point and spirit, and
constructed as it is in the business ami the dialogue of the scenes, furnish rich and ample scope
for the peculiar quaintness of manner that has
aequireu him the celebrity in which he may well
rejoice. H i s jokes and equivoque as he gave them
told to t h e utmost, and kept the house always in
the best of good humour, and called upon their
risible faculties most extravagantly.
T h e piece
has been got up in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, and w a s most
heartily congratulated. H« announced it for repetition every night amidst loud applause."—Bell's
Weekly Messenger.

" The p r i n c i p a l attraction at this theatre, on
W e d n e s d a y , was the fairy piece, O ' F L A N N I G A N
AND T H E F A I R I E S , in which Power wont through
the part with his usual buoyancy of spirit, a n d
produced shouts of laughter by his drolleries as
the unfortunate Phelim O'Flanmgan.
T h e piece
has been well got u p , and does infinite credit to
the management."—The, Age.
" On W e d n e s d a y night, a piece, entitled O'
F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , dramatized from

a collection of Irish Fairy Tales,after the fashion
of ' O'Rourke and the Eagle,' was produced with
g r e a t success. T h i s piece is grounded upon t h e
drunken adventures of 0 ' f 7 a n n j ' ^ a « ( M r . P O W E R )
who, in his potations, wanders among the fairies
on the eve of his marriage ; and his frolics among
the ' good people,' although not exactly in t h e
manner of Titania, O her onand Bully Bottom, are
irresistibly ludicrous.
Mrs. F I T Z W I L H A M , a s
Man/ his intended, looked, acted, and sang very
sweetly, and the bouse was in a roar from the commencement till the fall of the curtain."—Atlas.

" There is no theatre in London where a better evening's amusement can bo obtained than at
the Haymarket, or where a better company can be
found. O ' F L A N N I O A N AND T H E F A I R I E S , was
of course the principal attraction of the evening;
the bewilderment and incredulity of Phelim, are
comic in the highest degree, and do infinite
c r e d i t to M r . P O W E R ; he has also an e x cellent drunken scene, in which h i eons over by
the light of a lanthorn the rules and regulations
laid down by himself against future excess in his
' p u b l i c and private dhrinks,' and which, like
the final clauses of an actof parliament, have loopholes big enough to roll a do/en hogsheads of
whisky through them. T h e last act is hy far the
best, and in itself will repay the visitor. At its
conclusion, P O W E R informed the audience that
Mrs.O*Flanniijan
would have a 'small toy*party'
on the following evening, to which he invited
them a l l ; and fiom the hearty manner in which
they bestowed their applause, all seemed bent
upon 'making one.'—Sndtiy Times.
"O'Fl.ANNIGVN

AND T H E F A I I U E S J

" Mr. P O W E R , in a tale of the Irish fairies,
embodied all the humours and was a fit representative of all the gladness, that are peculiar to the
season. O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , a n
excellent comic romance by Mr. P O W E R himself,
will no doubt have a most successful holiday run."
—Examiner.
" P O W E R is the life and soul of the fun ; how
he breaks his vow of tee-totahsm and temperance,
(in the use of the Khibdagh,) and dreams a dream
full of grotesque horrors, and is transported to the
clouds in a donkey-cart.
T h e ' tight' and t h e
' j i g ' would be alone worth seeing, were there
nothing else to be enjoyed."—The Spectator.

Or, A

alleged not to
have been written by Shakspeare, gave an opportunity for th« irresistible comicality of P O W E R .
I t was for the first time produced at this theatre,
but will certainly not be the last, the audience
having testified their approbation in a very marked manner. T h e piece is altogether exceedingly
well got up, and gives opportunity for t h e indulgence of all P O W E R ' S peculiarities and humorous
songs, in which h e is most ably assisted by t h e
genuine simplicity and archness ot Mrs. F I T Z W I L L I A M , who personates Mary, in which elmr a c t e r s h e sings very sweetly two or three favorite
b a l l a d s . " - T h e Tore/,.

in

never were H a r l e q u i n , Columbine, Clown a n d

Literary
Gazette.
" O' PLANNIOAN

AND T H E F A I R I E S

is a

vehicle for Mr. P O W E R ' S inimitable Irishisms,
whimsicalities, and comicalities,whieh render him
the best delineator of true Irish character extant.
T h e piec» was very lau»hahle, and t h e dialogue
was occasionally relieved by a grotesque dance,
an Irish j i g , or a familiar a n d pleasing Iriah
melody, which excited considerable applause.
T h e piece was announced for repetitien without a
single dissentient voice"— Morning
lltraldif&lobe

" T h e H a y m a r k e t fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E R ' S own ingenuity, and owes all its Am
to his inimitable acting of t h e Irish • boy,' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking and fighting for a whole year;but, breaking it, he has a dream full of funny horrors, which
are enacted on the stage, tothe infinite amusement
of everybody ; t h e dreamer figuring, in propria
person*, as t h e hero of the droll adventures."—

Preceded b y A L E X A N D E R USE'S celebrated I r i s h M e d l e y Overture.
T h e M u s i c w i t h t h e e x c e p t i o n o f t w o P i e c e s , b y R.ODWEXX, s e l e c t e d f r o m p o p u l a r I r i s h M e l o d i e s .
ft** Tljere Is hardly n lonely valley or wild mountain range in nil Ireland, that l»nr>t characterized by name! denoting the residenca, or haunt of the " GOOD
Panel.-, oa F A I R I E S . " and <%« belief that these r//t» inhabitants of earth and air >>cca*ionally condescend to lnte> fere with mortals, either in mirth or In malace,
till lingers amongst the peasantry, one of the most poetical of onr national superstitions., and highly congenial to the temperament of an imaginative, people.
Ilits Drama, however, presents the " Omul People" In rlreain onl) , the action of the pirre, from the time the fairies appear, until the sleeping O'Flanuigan
m a k e s once more to a working day world, cxlstlafr only in the creations of a wild fellows brain fired by whiskey, and disordered by hard blows Hl»
imaginary perils and sttSerings being at ome the consequence of his intemperance, and the moral punishment of the relapsed whiskey lover.

P e o n s , on FAieiBi." and l!ie belief that these elfin inhahitauti of earth and air occHHionolly condeseend to Intrifrie with mortals, either in mirth or In veJa>e,
still lingers amonjrst tl.epeaaantty, one of the most poetical of our national superstitious, and highly congenial to iho tempeiameut of an iniaftinslive people.
Tliia Drama, howerer, preienU the " Oooil People" in driam only, the action of Ihe piece, from the time the fairies appear, until the sleeping O'Flaenigea
awakes once more t o e working day world, e l U t l . f only in the ereaiions of a wild fellow'* brain fired by whiskey, and disordered by bard blew., Mia

*' One of the best Christmas Pieces t h a t

hare
been produced is t h e amusing extravagan**
brought out a t t h e Haymarket, a n d called

T h e principal piece was O ' F I . A N N I O A M
iND T i l s F A I R I E S , the plot of which turns ou
tb» mystification which besets a good humoured
s a t i r e of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza atlurdedan opportunity fur the intioduetion
<jf P O W E R , whosa rich humour, combined with
hi* genuine Irish manner, kept the house in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
' O ' F l a n n i g a n ' s appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The
Time.

O ' F L A N R I G A N AND THK F A I H I Es, adramatiEing

of t h e Irish fairy legend, called, « H i e ove- to
England.' T h e r e are several amusing scenes in
the course of t h e piece, one of the best beiBg
the fair scene, with a skirmish among t h e boys,
ending with not a few broken heeds. I t were,
perhaps, needless to say that, - s to Power was
entrasted the task of delineating the pecutiarittee
of a light-hearted
ami light-headed broth of e
boy, he acquitted himself of his task, and t h e
piece was given out for repetition w i thou I a d i s sentient vOi€fc,"~~ Court Journal.

•'O'Fl.tNNlGAN AND THE F A J K I E S J or, A
M I D S U M M E R N I G H T ' S D R E A M , ( n o t Shakspeare's)
w a s produced for the first time. Mr. P O W E R infused into it all his wonted point and spirit, and
•constructed a s it is in the business and t h e dialopne of the scenes, furnish rich and ample scope
or the peculiar qunintness of manner that has
acquired him the celebrity in which he may well
rejoice. H i s jokes and equivoque as he gave them
told to t h e utmost, a n d kept the house always in
t h e best of good humour, and called upon their
risible faculties most extravagantly.
T h e piece
h a s been got u p in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, ami was most
heartily congratulated. l i e announced it for repetition every night amidst loud applause."-—IMVs
Weekly Messenger.

m

T h e r e is no theatre in London where a bett e r evening's amusement can be obtained than at
t h e Haymarket, or where a better company can be
fened. O ' F L A N N I G A N ANI» T H E F A I R I E S , was
of course the principal attraction of the evening;
t h e bewilderment and incredulity of Phvlim, a r e
«omic in t h e highest degree, and do infinite
c r e d i t to M r . P O W E R ; h e h a s also an e x cellent drunken aeene, in which he cons over by
the light of a lanthorn the rules and regulations
laid down by himself against future excess in his
' p u b l i c and private dhrink",' and which, like
the final clauses of M act of parliament, have loopholes big enough to roll a dozen hogsheads of
whisky through them. T h e Inst act is by far the
beat, and in its«lf will repay the visitor. At its
•oBclusion, P O W E R informed the audience that
Mr$»0,Flanni(jnn
would have a ' s m a l l tay party'
on the following evening, to which he invited
these a i l ; a n d from the hearty manner in which
they bestowed their applause, all seemed bent
. p o n ' m a k i n g one.'—Sunday Timet.
"O'Fl.ANNlO tN ANT) THE F A I R I E S , or, A
N I G H T ' S D R E A M , alleged not to
have been written by Shakspenre, cave an opportunity for t h e irrcsiNtible comicality of P O W E R .
I t wan for the first time produced at tin* theatre,
but will certbinly not be the last, the audience
having testified their approbation in a very marked manner. T h e piece is altogether exceedingly
well got up, and gives opportunity for t h e indulgence of all P O W E R ' S peculiarities and humorous
tongs, in which he is most ablv assisted bv the
genuine simplicity and archness ot M r s . F i T z WILLIAM, who person ites Mary, in which character t h e sings verv sweetly two or three favorite
ballade."— The Torek.
MIDSUMMER

" T h e H a y m a r k e t fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E R ' S own ingenuity, and owes all its fun
to bis inimitable acting of t h e Irish ' bay,' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking and fighting for a whole year;but, breaking it, he has a dream full of funny horrors, .vhieh
e r e enacted on the stage, to the infinite amusement
©f everybody ; t h e dreamer figuring, in propria
persona, as the here of the droll adventures."—
The.
Athenmm.
" O ' F L A N N I O A N A N » T H E F A I R I E S , in which
P O W E R is of course the »be-all and the end-all.*
T h e illustrious ' HibernianPersonator' is, if possible, more redolent of humour than ever. T h e
getting up of the piece is nnexceptionable, and it
w a s exceedingly well
reQeivodS'—WceklyDiapatch

T h e pria cipal attraction at this theatre, o .
Wednesday, wan the fairy piece, O ' F I A N N I G A *
AND T H E F A I R I E S , in which Power went through
the part with his usual buoyancy of spirit, a n d
produced shouts of laughter by his drolleries ae
the unfortunate Phelim O'Ftanmgun.
T h e piece
has been well got u p , a n d does infinite credit t o
the management.*'—T/i« Aye.

On W e d n e s d a y night, a piece, entitled O*

F T A N N I G A N A N D THK F A I R I E S , dramatized frosa

a collection of Irish Fairy Tales.after the fashion
of ' O ' R o u r k e and the Eagle,' was produced with
reat success. T h i s piece is grounded upon t h e
runken adventures of 0 ' f 7 « n « t ^ a a ( M r . P O W E R )
who, in his potations, wanders among the fairies
on the eve of his marriage ; and his frolics among
the ' good people,' although not exactly in t h e
manner of Titonia, Oberon and liully Hottamt are
irresistibly ludicrous.
M r s . F I T Z W U L I A M , ae
Mary his intended, looked, acted, and sang very
sweetly, and the house was in a roar from t h e commencement till the fall of the curtain."—Atlas,

f

" Mr. P O W E R , in a tale of the Irish fairies,
embodied all the humours and was a fit represesttative of all the gladness, that are peculiar to t h e
reason. O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , e a
excellent i,omic romance by Mr. P O W E R hinrself,
will no doubt have a m sjt successful holiday r u n . "
—Examiner.
" P O W E R is the life and seal of the f u n ; how
he breaks his vow of fee-totalism and temperttace,
(in the use of the shilei&gh,) and dreams a dream
full of grotesque horrors, and is transported to t h e
elonrls in a donkey-CJrt.
T h e ' fight' and t h e
• j i g ' would be alone worth seeing, were there
nothing else to be enjoyed."—The Spectator.
*• O ' F L A N N I G A N

A NO T H E F A I R I E S is co-

mie in t h e highest degree, and with t h e aid ef
singing, jigging, fighting, and fairy fun, we doubt
not that I ' O W E R ' 8 Phelim O Fianmgan will have
a most successful holiday run."—Post and Sum.

Literary
Gazette.
" O* Pl.ANNIGAN AND THE FAIRIES is a
vehicle for Mr P O W E R ' S inimitable Irishisms,
whimsicalities, and eomiealities.which render him
the bt-st delineator of true Irish character extant.
T h e piece was very laughable, and t h e dialogue
was occasionally relieved by a grotesque dance*
an Irish j i g , or a familiai ami pleading Irish
melody, which excited considerable applause.
T h e piece was announced for repetition w i t h o u t ,
single dissentient voice."
MorningHwraldffiilab*
'* All t h e fun of the piece, which i s of a
most extravagant and bustling character, rest,
upon the s h o u l d e n of our inimitable friend, Mr.
POWER.
I n a word, t h e audience were kept in a
rOar of laughter from the very outset to the final
fall of the curtain, and t h e piece was given out
for repetition every evening amidst a thunder of
applanse.—Chronicle.

SINCLE LIFE!

As the Comedy of -MARRIED LIFE* attempted to illustrate a lew of
the humours of the State Matrimonial* ami interest an Audience without
the Introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of-SINfiLE LIFE*
In going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters • LOVERS
ALL.* hopes to be equally successful in pourtraylng some of the vagaries
• f Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as wejl as the most loyal one of • The United States.*

SINCLE LIFE!

As the Comedy ot* MARRIED LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of *SIM<«LE LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVERS
ALL/ hopes to be equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickering* as well as the most loyal one of* The United States.*
BACHELORS.
Mr*J o h n Niggle,
(a fluctuating Bachelor)
Mr. WEBSTER,
Mr. David Damper,
{a Woman-hating Bachelor)
Mr. STRICKLAND,
Mr. Peter Pinkey,
(a hash f\'l Bachelor)

Mr. Narcissus Boss, - {a self-loving Bachelor) - Mr. WALTER LACY,
Mr. Charles Chester,
(a mysterious Bachelor)
Mr. HEMMING.

SINCLE LIFE!

the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of • t l l f i U I LIF1J*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters •LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to be equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and sho wing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of * The United States.*

SINGLE LIFE!
As the Comedy ot * MARRIED LIFE* attempted to Illustrate a few off
the humours off the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audienee without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of • SINGLE! LIFB"
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters «LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to he equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
wickering* as well as the most loyal one off * The United States.*

an

original CIWMMIV in lhr.»' Ada, by Mr. BIMHSTONR, called

SINGLE LIFE!

As the Comedy olvTIillRIEII LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, ami interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever ; the author o f SINGULIS LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVBRs
ALL,* hopes to he equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the mo»t loyal owe of* The United States.*

Ortgnnl Comedy in Three Acta, by Mr BOCKSTO-K, called

SINGLE LIFE!

As the Comedy ot * MARRIBO LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of • SINGLE L I F E '
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters -LOVERS
ALL,* hope* to he equally successful in pourtraving some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and sho wring that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of * The United States.*

SINCLE LIFE!

A§ the Comedy o f MARRIED)LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few or
t h e humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of * SINGLE LIITB*

ALL,* hoped to he equally successful In pourtravlug some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and she wing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of • The United States.*

SINGLE LIFE!

ALL/ hopes to he equally successful In pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showin; that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as th« mo*t loyal one of«The United States.*

.-dy in Thru An<, by Mr BUCKS! NF, called

LIFE!

As the Comedy ot • MARRIED LIFE* attempted to illustrate a lew of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of • SINGLE LIFE*
In going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to he equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of* The United States.*

SINGLE LIFE!

Ai tke Comedy of • KIARRIEO LIFE* attempted to illustrate a lew of
the humour* of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the Introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author o f • S l i t*na LIFE *
hi going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVttits
ALLt" hopes to be equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has Its
MoRerlngs as w e l l as the most loyal one of • The United States.*

" original Comal- in Three Acts, by Mr ButKsTONK, called

INCLE LIFE!

As the Comedy of- MARRIED LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of 'SINCSLK LIFK*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters -LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to be equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has it*
bickerings as well as th* most loyal one of- The United States.*

((/ fluctuating Bachelor)

OriZVIONfS of t h e PUBIiIC P R E S S .

*« Sir E. L. BULWKB obtained a new triumph last night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His uew
drams, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm w^th delight at the performance, we can
hardly . 1 any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same daw, and shews
extraordinary resource*, and a resstility of power fur which we
were nut fully prepared. We congratulate him less ban the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
audi a play, but the loss to the public, if h» did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is tu>re true than the m ittim, that, let a
man be-anted in any given circumstances, tl at man .ill Ve
found. Our National I'rama wan ed an author like Bulwer, and
he stood fui ward to fife t new rigour and aniuisti u. All the
performers well deseivrd ih* strongest testimony to tl eir rxcellene
V\ei annul pieteud t*< gothrmgh the differ'nt scenes and
situations of this adinir.blv-iouslrueictt dram i. I he < onclusiuu
of the Fourth Act is one of lite most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost o the
termination of the drama The writjng is bold and vigorous, and
tit a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the w.derarea of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete sati-faet.on. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more qu itati ms , but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole inhibition, from first to Inst, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
•« Sir E . L . Buiwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was aafe ; and the Sea-Captain finished bis voyage triumphantly."

—rtme*, Nov. Itl,

" Last night, was produced Sir E. I.. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the ' drop fell,' to speak with something likfr
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J..
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fiae a study of the part a* the part would
allow ; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
bis claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, wa».
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses,"—Morning Pott.
" The anuounretnejit of Sir E. Lytton Balwer's new Drama,.
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opemsd.
Every one anticipated a new triumph tor the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny fhat, as a theatrical repres-niatson, its triumph last night wa» complete. In the third and fou.'ith
acts the enthusiasm of lb* audience rose with the interest of The
Play, which was weB sustained in the fifth; till at length, at t;he
falling of the cortaiu, the audience aeStttd completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the
dramatis
permute were called tWward in succession, re receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally best or ted
•on them during (he progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Hul»er'» new play, THE SI'.A ( V l J I AIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last uiffht with a cast ot
•characters every way calculated to do a j i i t r e justice. 1fhe
atory is well W'rked out; Marrnady's part was especially vrell
auited ta him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. J . Webster gave out th« play for repetition ' every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good actio,- pl»y, abounding in what are
technically twined * good situations.'—Glohe, Nov. I, 1839.
" A new live Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytisii
Bulwer, entitled The S E A - C A P T A I N ; or, THE BIRTAN
R I G H T , was produced at this Theatre last evening. The sc.gne
is laid iu the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Eli aabeih— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists,
Maeresdy has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman His scene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and csills be* menial* to thrust him torth—he goes ti the
hearth, and invokes his ancestors to hail I heir SOB—bis sctmt, His
look, his utterance, wis sublimity itself. He was called for at
the^conr'usiou, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H. Taunt, and Stnt-hlatin. 'Hie Play was gtvtn out for repetition everj Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of One of the most crowatad hourtea
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated vesterday that the new pi.iv of Sir Edward I.ytioii
Buiwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIB t»U
R K i l l S , had been produced at this thcatn on the previous even,
ing, and that it had met with complete success. It is tri.ly
contemptible i.obaer*. with . h a t feeling and acumen the pnliHetl. bins of oui contemporaries of the daily press i< made snbienvient in their rc-sperme notices 1 this new play; as though
playright and politician waft synonymous leiiue, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock lor partisanship. Hud the author of the ' Birth*
right' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the menus of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
Jor what you-like) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays aud
polities. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, nud whose tendency, thus distinguislteef,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to tin iojttt of litrr.Uure,
and advantsge less the cause of the drama. But enough, We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright* is more replete with varied aud exciting interest than
either of the author • farmer productions, and is certainly not. less
rich in the poetic beauties: with winch his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of sink lag power and beaMty, which we have neither lime nor space now
to particularize. HM conception and action of the pait we«e all
that could be desir«tl» Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in th. performance; aud We haye no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense »>iti rest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
< « THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, has month* character of a romantic play than we have noticed in anv previous drama'ic effort ol the writer j and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, ita aflfet
unquestionably great and powerful. T h . pity, better acted than
it could possibly h<tvr been at any other place, > ecured its triumphant saceena."—Examiner.

" S i r Lytton Bulwer s new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
n •„• i d) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pla
are of kindred excellence. Theacene in the t'ld Hall, with its
carved puunels, its huge hiarth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Aruudle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects aud stirring situations ; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitfl '»). It will doubtless be extremely popular."—•Belt'*

" »n Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of THE SBA-CAPT \ !»; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced, I t i s a D r a m a
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee haa spared no exp'uee in the getting up of
th Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era-—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
hush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have arnn."—Age.

" 8 r E. L. Bulwer obtained a n w triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
Hiugew drama, called the SEA-CAPTA IN, is certain of a long
r u n r and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac'ion. It is of a character entirely different from his three

Weekly Me**enger.
** Ou Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five sets, by
Sir Edward Lytton B.lwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready some tine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a mister of human eaaotions

Weekly
Memengtr, Nor 3 , 1839.
•« Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a suci essful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
aud they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third ; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house; and Sir E. I.yiton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era,
" S i r P . I . Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this lime the tie flat binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mnnsions,' is beautiful, and
made ns forget that we were at the Hay-Market ; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid."—Athenaeum.
" A new Play entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
IHRTHRIGH 1, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. V> e think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immoiality either in plot or language, and the lattei is often very
pretty »nd occasionally poetical. We have isrelv seen Mr. Macready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."

— The Argut,
" The little. Th»atre, as it is still termed.through habit, though
not so little eithei, was crowded in evety part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lylton llulwer's new play of The SKA-CAPT A I N ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously

'i run.
It is eosual ;n poetic beauty and originality of thought
ti ft • " Ijidy of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—JoAn Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lytton Uulwer's new play, The SKA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday
ta«t. I he success was unequivocal and ci wiplete
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
«> have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such as Bulv i c«n write. In tin march of his plot the author has proved
if to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, ever* art terminating with a thrilling event, each suspending bj its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement. ' The acting
lhf(Hlgfeo*)t M t fine to perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sn E. Lytton Bnlwer may well laugh at newspaper critieism,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed muih more by political feeling than
hi sound dtM-retinn and fair ludgment. They could not deny
that bit new drama, The S E A - C A P ? A W , met with the most
triumphant success, but the) did their *' little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
l hole there, to establish tin vi.rthlessneas of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean lone after the first run, and long even after the first season."—Oftaerrer.
" (luThursday aightthi SKA-CAPTAIN made bis first voyIge > r perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe ami sound, not only
in the baved of love, but, what is of more consequence t<> actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinion*."—Pnrlhainn,
• ' S i r E . L, Bulwer's Play, m Five Acts, called The SEA*

" On Thursday, Sir Edward L. Bulwer's play of THE 8EA( i P T A I N ; or T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here t . a B
nee crowded in iver\ part, ami with the most unbounded
end deserved success. • .Most destrved,' for both in action and
poetry it is a noble dramatic prodtrctiea ; the plot aud leading
Characters possessing much originality, and the incidents aud
situations turuttij- upon them being, consequently, novel and
i ffeetive. Nothing could exceed the success of the whole, and
the management may put on iis nightcap foi the res* of the
B, while the public crowd to have their every night* enjoyments of a public drama acted in l masterly style. The period is
the Elizabethan age."—Literary Garett*.

O P I N I O N S of the FUBI.IO F R S S S
" Sir E. I.. B O L W B R obtained a new Iriumph last night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
it eertain of a long run ; and coining immediately from the representation, and warm wuh delight at the performance, we ran
hardly sec any end to ita attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shew*
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him leas than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satisfied with the possesion of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
b« irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let •
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
f.uhd. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he stood foi ward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
•ituations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to fa. when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-ronstructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
toauthor, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronidr.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— T i m e s , Not). 1st.
'' Last night, was produced Sir E. L. Bulwer's new drama of
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the 'drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete siircess. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to lie found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and bis action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his. guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered tor several minutes. We have no space, however, to eay
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Pott.
*' The announcement ol Sir E. Lytton ISulwer's new Drama,
T H E SI A-CAPTAIN ; or, I HE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opemd.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, nod it would
be the height of injustice to deny thai, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete, lu tin third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of UN audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of die curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away By their irciings, and nearly tne wtiuh of the Aramati*
personm were called forward in succession, lo receive I repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.

Sir Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIU ; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant succest. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. Fothe sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the sues.**
which attended its production. The acting of all the characteris admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Play
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with i t .
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor'* story, is the most
btttttifa picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
instron;" effects and stirring situations j there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bull'* Life in
London.
" On Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. I t i s a D r a m .
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
he Play, The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with th«
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pen of Sir E. L Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play. THE SF.A-CAPTA1N, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities o r producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a loag career."—Weekly Dispatch, Nov. I.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph oo Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to he a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writingis bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Messenger,
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwrr, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready sonar fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful.*'—New Bell's
Weekly
Messenger, Nov 3 , 1S30.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before ihe curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered (hat Bulwer was a suceea*f«l dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third J but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the art fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house; and Sir E. Lylton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumph., of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's new Play of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
T HE BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtont at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim In he
bet sen, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
" • * ns forget that we were at the Hay-Market ; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid.''— ithenmum.

" S i r E , L, B u i v r - n obtained a n e w t r i u m p h last night, and
every respect it i* likely to b e s lasting t r i u m p h .
Mis new
d r a m a , called T h e S E A - C A P T A I N ; o r , T H E B I R T H R I G H T ,
is certain of a long run ; and coining immediately from (he r a p n
sentation, and w a r m with delight at the performance, we r a n
hardly MS a n y end to ita attraction. I t ia M l character entirely
different from h i t three other w o r k s of the same class, and ahewa
Wttrsordinary reaoureea, and a versatility of power for which we
w e r e not fully p r e p a r e d . W e congratulate him leas than the town
wi t h e h a p p y r e s u l t of the experiment of last n i g h t ; for h e
m i g h t reat satisfied with the possession of the faculty to p r o d u c e
M M a p l a y , but t h e loss to t h e p u b l i c , if he did not w r i t e , would
be irreparable, Wothing is more t r u e than the m a x i m , that, let a
m a n be wanted in any given c i r c u m s t a n c e s , that m a n will be
found. O u t National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
h e stood fotward to give it new r i g o u r and animation. All t h e
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. W e cannot pretend to go through the different scenesand
aituations of this a d m i r a b l y - e m i s t r u c t t d drama. T h e conclusion
of the Fourth Act ia one of the most stirring and a n i m a t i n g scenes
we. remember M the s t a g e , but we despair of g i v i n g any notion
• f the plot, which ean convey to t h e reader even a faint notion of
t h e interest e x c i t e d , and the suspense carried o n , almost to t h e
termination of the d r a m a . The. w r i t i n g is hold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the H a y - M a t k i t it is not thrown away, as
it often a p p e a r s to b e when delivered in the wider area of a large
t h e a t r e . W e d o not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction.
We heartily
wiih we had time and spare for a few more ((nutations j but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our r e a d e r - will have m o r e delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. T h e whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded HtiraiM d gratification
to author, a c t o r s , and a u d i e n c e . " — M o r n i n g

wag produced last night. T h e last Scene in t h e Fourth A c t , is

•* Last n i g h t , was produced S i r E . I.. Bolwer's n e w d r a m a of
T H E S E A - C A P T A I N ; or, T H E B I R T H I U G H T . T h e play
itself was completely successful. T h e scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the ' d r o p fell,' t o speak with something like
• execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally M r . J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for r e p e t i tion ' every evening uotil further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and braves, confirmatory ol complete success. I t contains p a s s a g e of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
• r e to b e found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as tine a study of the part as t h e p a r t would
allow ; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
-surni, powerful, energetic.
I he passage where Norman
asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord A r u n d e l , w a s
cheered for several minutes. W t have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
w e have no doubt, draw. It ha* been carefully got u p , with new
s e e m i y and d r u i r s . " — M o r n i n g
Pout.

" T h e announcement ol S i r E . I.ytiou Bnlwcr's new Drama,
T H E S l i A - C A P T A l N ; or, T B I B I R T H R I G H T , drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat nut previously
engaged, b e i n g occupied almost as soon as the doors *i ere opened.
Every one atitu ipated a new t r i u m p h for the A u t h o r , and it would
b e t h e height of imiisti.e to dony t h a t , as a theatrical rt presentation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth

Arnndle a n d Violet listening to the. sailor's story, is t h e most
b*autiful p i c t u r e we have seen for many a d a y . T h e Play abounds
in strong eflects and s t i r r i n g situations ; there a r e some exquisite
figures, <ome very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless b e extremely p o p u l a r . " — B e l l ' s Life in

*' S i r E . I.. Bulwer obtained a m-w triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new d r a m a , called the S K A - C A P T A I N , is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately trom the representation, and warm
with d. light at t h e performance, we can hardly see an end t o ita
a l t r a r 'ion. I t ia of a character entirely different from h i s three
other works of t h e same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
T h e w r i t i n g i s bold and v i g o r o u s . " — B e l V s Weekly

" Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir K. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this T h e a t r e . T h e announcement nttraeted si
crowded audience, and before the c u r i a m rose t h e house was
crammed to t h e roof
T h e y remembered llmt Bulwer was a s u c cessful dramatist, a n d , beyond all question, a man of . g e n i u s ;
und they s a w before them on the M m a constellation of talent,
such as could b e produred at no other Theatre in London. T h e
interest opened in t h e second a c t , and increased in the t h i r d ; b u t
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the i m p . tuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of t h e a r t fell amidst t h u n d e r s of
tumultuous a p p l a u s e , upon one of t h e most successful pieces we
ever saw. T h e piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
utile, h o u s e ; a n d S i r E . I.jitou Bulwer, owing as much t o t h e
excellence of the acting as to h i s own p . W W , has achieved by it
one of'the greatest triumphs of his jrenitis."—Era..
" . N . r E . L . B u l w e r ' s new P l a , of T H E S E A - C A P T A I N ; o r ,

his r i g h t of h e i r s h i p , defving t h e menials who had been called to
eject him, producer! a striking effect. The. Scenery, taken p r i n cipally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made ut> forget that « I were M t h e H a y - M a r k e t ; and the costumes a r e a p p r o p r i a t e and s p l e n d i d . " — A t h e n e e u m .

OFXIUIOIUS of t h e P U B L I C P R E S S .
«' Sir E. IN BULWRR obtained a new triumph last night, and
in every respect it in likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT,
it certain of a long; run ; and coining immediately from the representation, and, warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to it* attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three, other works of the same class, and shew*
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fidly prepared. We congratulate him lens than the town
Mi the happy result of the experiment of last night; for lie
night rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
saeh a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
f.und. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwei, and
he stood forward to give it new rigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost l« the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Msrket it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be .hen delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sut out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that o u r r m ders will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Sceue in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and th« Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— Time*, Nov. 1*1.
«' Last night, was produced Sir E. L. Bulwer's new drama of
THE 8EA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scene* were applauded all
through ; and when the 'drop fell,' to speak with something,like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; ami finally Mr. J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice," amid plenty of applaus.
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It c.ntains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Maercady made as fige a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no spare, however, tr«say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally ssccessful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been can-fully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Pott.
" The announcement o( Sir E. Lytton Bulwer's new Duma,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, drew an werflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, lifting occupied almos« as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it mould
I'tthe height of injustice to deny that, »s a theatrical reprer»nta~
ion,its triumph last night was complete. In the third and i mirth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest o-f the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, a it the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the drai natu
permmm were called forward in succession, to receive a rep« Hition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally best 'owed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier *.
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in pre paraxon at this theatre, was brought out last night with a c ast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice.
The
story is well worked out; Macready's part was especially well
suited t . him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advari 'tags.
Mr. J. Webster gave omt the play for repetition • every tvi ;ning
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most general appl tsuse.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in win it are
technically termed ' good situations. —Globe, Nov. I, 188 19.
" A new Five Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward I ,ytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BI1 I T H RMJHT, was prodnred at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen I filizsbelh— the time, occupied by the action is one day ; a I tearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dram atists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his bes .utiful
impersonation of Norman. His ucene with his mother, whi «re he
make* himself known to her, was magnificent. She denir * his
claim, and calls her menials to tlitust him forth—he goes t to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor? to hail their son—his actio B, his
look, his utterance, was sublimity itself. He was called f or at
the conclusion, as were Mr*.Warner, Miss H. Faucit, and 8l trick,
land. The Play was given out for repetition every Eve -ring,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded h KIUSCS
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward 1 .ytton
rer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BI1 I T H HT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible t« observe with what feeling and acumen t h e p i>i«ft»
tttl bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made su bser.
•Sent in their respective notices of this new plays as through
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the dri una a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the < B irthrighr been known only as a dramatic author, the public - 'ould
irobably have been afforded, through the press, the mea u* of
udging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the d rama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or ' Tory
(or what you-like) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as c litScult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between playi i and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whore observance of j. tarty
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distingnis Bed,
is to the antipodes) will add but little lo the lustre of literal ore,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern -our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
' Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest Oian
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
r>ch in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound- Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor .space'now
to partlculariue. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable W the entire cast in the performance ; and we haye no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazelle.

K
J

" THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E BIRTHR1GH 1, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer ; and, read or viewed wiih the
half o* that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its trinmphanv success."—Examiner.
