«NaWu"
•

" S i r Lytton Bulwer's new Play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
She sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Plsy
are of kindred excellence The scene in th«> Old Hall, with its
carved pnnnels, it* huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen formany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell** Life in
London
" On Thursday, S i r E . L Bulwer's Play of T H E SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced- ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we car. speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age,
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pea of Sir E. I... Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Tharsdsy night, with decided success The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."—Weekly ftitpatch, Nov. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain"of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to it*
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resource,
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous "—Bell'* Weekly Me**enger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotion,
and passions, it was very successful."—New Bell'*
Weekly
Me**enger, Nov. 3 , 1839.
'* La<Jt Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius ;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second art, and increased in the third ; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one ot Ihe most successful pieces we
ever saw, The piece, in fact, was performed as it ean be in no
other house; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to t h t
ex-ellence of the acting a*- to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . 1 . Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtout at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to b .
her son, and be takes his stand on hi* paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid.'"—Athenmum.
" A new Play entitled T H E 8EA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Maoready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
—The ArgMt.
" The little Theatre,as it is still termed,through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in every part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious lo assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was tapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a r*m. It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the " Lady of Lyons," or - Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced (or the first time at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and complete
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
we haw ever seen or heard. The dialogue i» only such as Bulwor««a write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act terminating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection,"—Court Journal.
